The patient's history of smoking and physical examination findings suggest the diagnosis of pulmonary fibrosis, which is characterized by excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung. This can lead to decreased lung compliance and impaired gas exchange, causing dyspnea on exertion. The CT scan findings are also consistent with this diagnosis. Chronic airway inflammation, pleural scarring, and increased pulmonary artery pressure are not typically associated with pulmonary fibrosis.

The physical examination findings such as enlarged fingertips and nail curving, inspiratory crackles, and the CT scan confirming clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung support this diagnosis. Chronic airway inflammation would be seen in conditions like COPD or asthma, which do not fit with the patient’s clinical picture. Pleural scarring would result in restrictive lung disease without airway symptoms. Increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries is a feature of pulmonary arterial hypertension, which is not supported by the physical examination findings in this patient.
